document.docTitle: Passiflora coelestis Parteka & Silverio 2021, sp. nov.
document.masterDocTitle: Passiflora coelestis, a new species of Passiflora section Dysosmia (Passifloraceae sensu stricto) from Southern Brazil

paragraph.heading:
Passiflora coelestis Parteka & Silvério
,
sp. nov .
( Figs. 5 and 6 ).

subSubSection.paragraph:
TYPE :— Brazil . Paraná . Pinhão : Faxinal do Céu , 25º55’07.85”S , 51º35’50.69”W ,
20 November 2014
,
A . Suchoronczek
&
A . Silvério s.n.
( holotype : HCF6355 !; isotype: MBM 397156 !)
.

Diagnosis :—
Passiflora coelestis
is morphologically related to
P. campanulata
; however, it can be distinguished by its stipules reniform with falciform apex and slightly glandular and serrated margins, while the stipules of
P. campanulata
are semi-ovate with cuspidateacuminate, and denticulate towards the base;
P. coelestis
presents petiole pilose with deciduous secreting trichomes without nectary while
P. campanulata
presents nectar secreting glands near the middle.

Description :—Ligneous and pilose low-sprawled liana. Stalk thin, cylindrical, green occasionally brown and pilose with white trichomes when young, ramified next to the ground. Stipules reniform, falciform at apex, 5–8 × 3–4.5 mm , margins slightly glandular, serrated, pilose on abaxial face, falciform region of adaxial face with white trichomes. Leaves petiolate, petioles 1.9–2.3 cm long, green and brown, pilose with white and deciduous secreting trichomes, without nectary; leaf blade simple with three lobes, deeply hastiform, 3-lobed with acuminate apex, 4.4–5.8 long × 5.3– 6.6 cm wide, lobes elliptic, acute at apex, central lobe larger than lateral lobes, pilose with white trichomes on adaxial and abaxial surfaces, entire margin with trichomes, with a possibility for glands in the area of transition between lobes. Bracts lanceolate-linear with acuminate apex, 15 × 4–8 cm , deeply dentate, pilose with white trichomes. Peduncles solitary, ca. 14 cm long, reddish-brown, pilose with white trichomes. Flowers short-campanulate, hanging, white and light red; sepals oblong-linear with rounded apex, ca. 20 × 5 mm , white on adaxial surface, pale green on abaxial surface, pilose with white trichomes on pale green veins, keels pilose with white trichomes, ca. 2 mm long; petals oblong-linear with rounded apex, ca. 22 × 4 mm , membranous, white. Corona filaments with 3 to 4 series, 1 inner and 2 to 3 outer series, 1.5–1.8 cm long, filiform, apex white with red speckled bands around the bottom half, red at the base, thin filiform interior series 3–4.5 mm long, red with white apex. Operculum erect, membranous, thick at base, slightly bent in region of apex next to filaments, ca. 6 mm long, opercular filaments of top half free, red with a white apex, ca. 4 mm long. Limen disk-shaped, thick and membranous on the base, meets the apex region and is covered by the operculum, ca. 2 mm long. Androgynophore 6–7 × 1.5 mm , greenish-white. Ovary green, ovoid, extremely pilose. Style yellowish-cream, base pilose leaving the ovary. Stigma greenish-white. Pollen grain 12-colpate, prolatespheroidal. Fruit berry-like, ovoid, pilose with white trichomes, light green-yellow when immature. Seeds unseen.

caption.paragraph:
FIGURE 5. Illustration of
Passiflora coelestis Parteka & Silvério
, new species (illustration by Daiane Gonçalves Ferreira).

FIGURE 6.
Passiflora coelestis Parteka & Silvério
, new species . Stipule reniform with falciform apex and margins slightly glandular sedated (a, b and c); petiole pilose with deciduous secreting trichomes with no nectary (d, e and f); detail of the deciduous secreting trichomes (e); leaf trilobed pilose (g); middle of the lobes with glands (h); bracts linear lanceolate with acuminate apex, deeply jagged, pilose (i); nectary region (circle) and corona with a series of thin filiform inner filaments, red with white apex and four series of outer long filiform filaments, white on the apex with the red speckled band around the bottom half and red on the base (arrows) (j); flower short campanulate, hanging, white and light red (k); androgynophore with elevated androecium and gynoecium and ovary ovoid pilose (1) (photos by L. M. Parteka and A. Silvério). Scale bars g—1cm.

subSubSection.paragraph:
Etymology :—The epithet “
coelestis
” refers to Faxinal do Céu, the place where the plant was found, with “Céu” meaning “heaven” in the Portuguese language.
Phenology :—Flowering and fruiting occur from October to December.
Distribution and Habitat :— Paraná State , Brazil . Grows in Atlantic Forest, Araucaria Moist Forest, on ground with litterfall, above 1041 m .a.s.l.

Examined specimens for other species of Dysosmioides group
:—
Passiflora boticarioana
